title: 114_s2040
content: The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" aims to address international terrorism's impact on the United States, including harm to commerce and travel. It recognizes the need for legal action against those aiding and abetting terrorism. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" establishes liability for those who knowingly support terrorism, aiming to provide victims of terrorist attacks in the United States access to the court system for civil claims. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" allows civil litigants to pursue claims against individuals, entities, or countries that have supported terrorist activities against the United States. It aims to provide a broad basis for seeking relief and holds foreign states accountable for international terrorism. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" allows civil litigants to pursue claims against foreign states in the United States for physical injury, property damage, or death caused by acts of international terrorism or tortious acts committed by the foreign state or its officials. Nationals of the United States can bring claims against foreign states that would not be immune under this act. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" allows civil litigants to pursue claims against foreign states in the United States for acts of international terrorism or tortious acts. Amendments are made to the table of sections for chapter 97 of title 28, United States Code. "1605B. Responsibility of foreign states for international terrorism against the United States." Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include liability for aiding and abetting in civil actions regarding terrorist acts. Liability can be asserted on any person who aids and abets, by knowingly providing substantial assistance, or conspires with the person who committed the act of international terrorism. The amendment does not affect the immunity of a foreign state under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction over actions involving a foreign state under section 1605B of title 28. The Attorney General can intervene to seek a stay of the civil action if the Secretary of State certifies ongoing discussions with the foreign state defendant. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or any amendment made by this Act is held invalid, the rest of the Act and amendments remain valid. The amendments made by this Act apply to civil actions pending or commenced after the date of enactment and arising from injuries after September 11, 2001.
